data.title: Find the Shortest Sentence Path
data.solution:
n = gets.to_i
links = {}
links.default = []
n.times do
  word_1, word_2 = gets.split(" ")
  links[word_1] += [word_2]
end
start = "I"
queue = links[start].map{|node| [node, [start, node] ] }
until queue.any?{|node, path| node.include?(?.) }
  queue = queue.flat_map{|current, path| options = links[current]
    options.map{|node| [node, path + [node] ] } }
end
path = queue.find{|node, path| node.include?(?.) }.last
puts path*" "
data.statement:
Modern devices usually have an 'auto-complete' or 'predictive text' feature whereby words that commonly follow one another can be used to predict the next word you wish to type.

Here, you are given an integer [[n]], then [[n]] pairs of words that are allowed to be used in a sentence together (one-way, not in reverse). Using these pairs, find the shortest {{sentence-chain}} possible that begins with the word {{I}} and ends with a word that has a full stop (period) {{.}} (e.g. {{cat.}} might finish the sentence {{I have a cat.}}).

<<Shortest>> is defined by word count. Sentences must start with the word {{I}}, not {{I'll}} or {{I'd}} or similar.

Note: There can be multiple start and end points for possible sentences, so you need to focus on finding the <<shortest possible sentence>> if you want to score 100%.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

Modern devices usually have an 'auto-complete' or 'predictive text' feature whereby words that commonly follow one another can be used to predict the next word you wish to type.

Here, you are given an integer n, then n pairs of words that are allowed to be used in a sentence together (one-way, not in reverse). Using these pairs, find the shortest sentence-chain possible that begins with the word I and ends with a word that has a full stop (period) . (e.g. cat. might finish the sentence I have a cat.).

Shortest is defined by word count. Sentences must start with the word I, not I'll or I'd or similar.

Note: There can be multiple start and end points for possible sentences, so you need to focus on finding the shortest possible sentence if you want to score 100%.
Input
Line 1: An integer n for the number of word pairs available.
Next n lines: Pairs of space separated words that can be chained together to form a sentence
Output
One line: The shortest possible sentence (by word count) as a space separated chain of words, beginning with I and ending with a full stop. (e.g. I have a cat.)
Constraints
1 < n < 300
It is guaranteed that there will never be more than one shortest possible sentence(i.e. no ties).
There will also not be any ! or ? marks in the inputs, so a . is the only way to end a sentence.
Example
Input
7
have a
named Jack.
I had
a cat
had bad
I have
cat named
Output
I have a cat named Jack.
